body:
@adg every one of them, as someone who writes and/or reads and runs the test - without manually checking the random data - most probably will think the test runs with different data each time, when in fact it's the same data each time. yes, the data otherwise would be random, and as such only at random problems will be highlighted, but like this in tests thatâ€™s never the case.

this is especially true with out of bounds testing and shifting etc. especially with fuzzing.
